results.title: Peer pressure trigger tapes (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Three exciting short films about peer pressure, 1)”Sticks and Toby”. Two best friends, a thin boy and a fat boy go swimming. Toby , the fat boy, is teased by a group of boys who want Sticks to join them. What should Sticks do? “The Gang”; Ting Lee wants to join a gang at her school. In her new hairstyle and jacket they finally accept her, but then they pressure her to smoke! “Tough Rules” Max and his friends do lots of fun things together. One day they decide they should each steal something, Max doesn’t like stealing , but doesn’t want to lose his friends.

results.title: Peer conducted behaviour modification (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Phillip R. Blake and Steven D McAdam
results.brief_description: Drs. Clement and Paterson discuss the roles of peers in child therapy. The film shows a program at the Oregon Institute which, having found that the child’s peers can undermine the work of both psychologists and parents, uses other children to reinforce the behaviour therapy.

results.title: Peeping Tom
results.creator_credit: Michael Powell (Theatre) Ltd and Michael Powell
results.brief_description: A withdrawn psychopath films young women as he impales them with the camera’s tripod, forcing them to watch their own death throes in a mirror mounted on the camera. Now considered a masterpiece, Michael Powell’s film foreshadowed the slasher genre.

constellations_other.name: Capturing first-person POV
constellations_other.description: A comparison of how videogames and feature films have used first person POV shots and sequences and how (for the latter) camera technology has impacted on this.

results.description: In 1960 “Peeping Tom” took a ferocious drubbing from the English critical establishment. Powell saw it not as a horror film but ‘a film of compassion, of observation and of memory … a film about the cinema from 1900 to 1960 … the opposite to a realistic film … a reverie’. A withdrawn psychopath, traumatised by childhood memories, films young women as he impales them with the camera’s tripod, forcing them to watch their own death throes in a mirror mounted on the camera. This is rendered genuinely disturbing as we are drawn into identification with the protagonist through Carl Boehm’s subtly controlled performance. Littered with internal cross references, this is a reflexively subversive film about the fascination of cinema, a film which seeks to make voyeurs of us all. Cast also includes Moira Shearer, Anna Massey and Maxine Audley.

Powell saw it not as a horror film but ‘a film of compassion, of observation and of memory … a film about the cinema from 1900 to 1960 … the opposite to a realistic film … a reverie’. A withdrawn psychopath, traumatised by childhood memories, films young women as he impales them with the camera’s tripod, forcing them to watch their own death throes in a mirror mounted on the camera. This is rendered genuinely disturbing as we are drawn into identification with the protagonist through Carl Boehm’s subtly controlled performance. Littered with internal cross references, this is a reflexively subversive film about the fascination of cinema, a film which seeks to make voyeurs of us all. Cast also includes Moira Shearer, Anna Massey and Maxine Audley.

results.title: Peep-peep-peep
results.brief_description: Puppet animated film about the Wombles who live under Wimbledon Common in London. In this episode the Wombles discover a crude version of the telephone by using tins and string. Based on the children’s book series The Wombles by Elizabeth Beresford. Suitable for middle and upper primary level.

results.title: Peege
results.creator_credit: Bedford Productions, Phoenix Films, David Knapp, Leonard S. Berman and Randal Kleiser
results.brief_description: A family visits their grandmother, who is in a nursing home, on Christmas Day. Peege, as they call their grandmother, is nearly blind and her mental and physical capacities are failing. Through a number of flashbacks the eldest grandson remembers her as she was when he was a child - full of vitality and laughter. When the others leave he talks to her of the old times, and breaks through her isolation. Cast includes Bruce Davison, Jeanette Nolan, William Shallert, Barry Livingston, David Alan Bailey, Barbara Rush.

results.title: Pecker
results.creator_credit: Fine Line Features, Polar Entertainment, John Fiedler, Mark Tarlov and John Waters
results.brief_description: Written and directed by John Waters (Pink Flamingos, Hairspray, Serial Mom), ‘Pecker’ is an offbeat comedy set in Baltimore, Waters’ hometown. Pecker (Edward Furlong) is a happy-go-lucky 18 year old who likes nothing better than to take candid photographs of his eccentric family and friends, as well as unusual aspects of his environment. Pecker’s family consist of: Mom (Mary Kay Place) who spends her days dispensing fashion tips to the homeless; sister Tina (Martha Plimpton) who spruiks at a local gay strip bar; grandmother, (Jean Schertler) who receives religious messages from her Holy statue of Mary; and six year old sister Chrissy who is suffering from an eating disorder. Shelly (Christina Ricci) is Pecker’s girlfriend who runs a laundromat and encourages his artistic endeavours. At an exhibition of his work, Pecker is “discovered” by Rorey (Lili Taylor), a New York art dealer who promises him fame and fortune. Pecker’s notoriety brings public ridicule to those nearest and dearest to him and threatens the integrity of his art. Also starring Mink Stole, Bess Armstrong, Brendan Sexton III, with a cameo from photographer Cindy Sherman.

results.title: Pecheur D'islande = Iceland Fisherman (Cinemascope Print)
results.creator_credit: Georges de Beauregard and Pierre Schoendoerffer
results.brief_description:
Yann, a sailor, is in charge of the ‘Pecheur d’Islande’, a fishing boat said to be jinxed. The boat belongs to Mevel, a rich ship owner whose daughter, Gaud, is in love with Yann. After Gaud’s father becomes bankrupt, Gaud and Yann get married. But their happiness is short-lived. A week after their wedding, Yann goes back to sea while Gaud must struggle to adapt a life of endless waiting. ‘Pecheur d’Islande’ revealed to a vast audience the epic story of the fishing expeditions to the arctic seas.

Credits: Producer, Georges de Beauregard ; director, Pierre Schoendoerffer ; writers, Pierre Schoendoerffer, Andre Tabet ; photography ; Raoul Coutard ; music, Charles Aznavour.
Cast: Jean-Claude Pascal, Juliette Mayhiel, Charles Vanel, Georges Poujouly.

results.title: Peau D'ane = Donkey Skin
results.brief_description:
In a fairytale kingdom, the King swore to his dying wife that he will not remarry unless his new wife was as beautiful as she. Thus, he is compelled to wed his own daughter. The fairy godmother tries to save the girl from this incestuous fate by telling her to make impossible demands for her wedding gifts. One such demand is for the skin of a magic donkey who serves as the King’s banker. Demy’s homage to ‘Snow White’ and ‘Beauty and the beast’ suffers at times from very a kitsch art direction. It has, with time, achieved cult status in France and become a family favourite.

Credits: Producer, Philippe Dussart ; director, Jacques Demy ; writer, Jacques Demy ; photography, Ghislain Cloquet ; music, Michel Legrand.
Cast: Catherine Deneuve, Jacques Perrin, Jean Marais, Delphine Seyrig, Micheline Presle, Fernand Ledoux, Pierre Repp, Sacha Pitoeff, Henri Cremieux, Sylvain Corthet.

results.title: Pearson Island
results.brief_description: Pearson Island, in the Great Australian Bight, supports a varied native fauna. Sea-lions live there permanently, and the sea birds include penguins, terns, oyster-catchers and Cape Barron geese. Saltbush and she-oak forest on higher ground have land birds and a native rat and wallaby extinct elsewhere. Commentary by Roger Cardwell.
